In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have started to earn more money and have escaped poverty. Additionally, six million fewer children die from disease every year, millions more girls are going to school, and many more people now have access to clean water.

original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
simplified: Feedback is information about a person's work. Many managers say something good. Then, they say something bad. After that, they say something good again. Workers start to think the good words are not real. They think the good words are only there for the bad information. So the good words become less important. Managers should use good words differently. They should use them to support good work. This helps workers do more good work.

original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
simplified: Many managers try to add something positive to their **feedback**, which is information about someone's work, by putting a negative comment between two positive ones. However, when this becomes a routine, employees may start to think that the positive comments are only there to make the negative ones seem less bad. As a result, the positive feedback loses its value. Instead, positive feedback should not just be used to soften negative comments, but it should be given to support and encourage good work.

original: I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the movie image of a terrifying Terminator stamping on human skulls and think of what's happening right now: military machines like drones, gun turrets and sentry robots are already being used to kill with very little human input. The next step will be autonomous 'murderbots', following orders but ultimately deciding who to kill on their own. It seems clear to me that this would be completely unethical and dangerous for humanity. We need to be very cautious indeed about what we ask machines to do.
simplified:
I am in a group called the 'Campaign to Stop Killer Robots'. We want to stop robots that kill.

Killer robots are not like in the movies. They are not scary robots from a film. But they are real now. Soldiers use machines like drones, gun turrets, and sentry robots. These machines kill people. A person gives very little help.

Soon, there will be robots that kill on their own. They will follow orders. But they will decide who to kill.

I think this is completely wrong. It is very dangerous for all people. We need to be very careful. We must think about what we ask machines to do.

The next step will be autonomous 'murderbots', following orders but ultimately deciding who to kill on their own. Military machines, like drones and gun robots, are already being used to kill with very little human control. The next step will be robots that work by themselves, which will follow orders but finally decide who to kill on their own. It seems clear to me that this would be completely wrong and very dangerous for all people. We need to be very careful indeed about what we ask machines to do.

However, Chinese has by far the greatest number of native speakers. There seems to be little correlation between how many native speakers there are of a language and the number of learners, but there is a stronger link between the number of learners and how many countries have speakers.
simplified:
More people learn English than all other languages together.
People speak English in the most countries.
But Chinese is different.
More people speak Chinese from birth than any other language.
The number of native speakers is not the most important reason to learn a language.
But the number of countries where people speak it is very important.

There seems to be only a weak connection between the number of native speakers a language has and the number of people who learn it, but there is a stronger link between the number of learners and how many countries have speakers.

original: Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. When you step into her office on Monday morning she begins by praising you for the good work you've done on the project, and you wonder if this is the obligatory praise that starts off the typical 'feedback sandwich'. You know how the feedback sandwich goes: say something nice, say what you really want to say, say something nice again.
simplified:
Your manager stops you. She wants to talk about your work on a project. You worry about it all weekend. You think you did something wrong.

On Monday morning, you go into her office. She starts and says you did good work. But you think this is the start of a 'feedback sandwich'.

A feedback sandwich is a special way to talk. First, you say something nice. Then, you say the bad thing. Then, you say something nice again.

original: A fast-paced, foot-tapping rock album, Born in the USA's lyrics nevertheless carry emotional weight. Behind the catchy rock melodies that drive these powerhouse classics are stories of the dark side of the American dream. Many tracks deal with the struggles of hard-working ordinary people and the bitterness and anger they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. It's not hard to imagine that the artist is channelling real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a star. The album will leave you in no doubt of the unique and extraordinary talent of the Boss.
simplified:
"Born in the USA" is a rock album. The music is fast. It makes you want to move your feet. But the words in the songs have deep and important feelings.

The music is easy to remember. The songs are powerful rock classics. But the stories are about the dark side of the American dream. Many songs are about the struggles of hard-working ordinary people. They do not become rich or famous. So they feel angry and unhappy about their lives.

For example, one song is "Glory Days". It is about people in a small town. They think about the past. They were young and had a great future. Another song is "Downbound Train". It tells the story of a young man. He loses his job. His life is ruined after this.

The artist probably knew real people like this. He writes about their lives. Maybe his life was going to be like that. But then he became a star. This album makes it clear the artist is special. He is called "the Boss". He has a great skill for music.

The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. It's not hard to imagine that the artist is channelling real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a star. Behind the catchy rock music of these powerful and famous songs, there are stories about the negative side of the American dream. Many songs are about the problems of ordinary, hard-working people and the anger they feel when life does not bring them money or success. For example, the song 'Glory Days' is about people in a small town who are looking back at their youth, when they felt they had a great future. Another song, 'Downbound Train', tells the story of a young man whose life is destroyed after he loses his job. It is easy to imagine that the artist is writing about real people he knew, and also about the life he might have had if he had not become a star. The album clearly shows the special and amazing talent of 'the Boss'.

original: Lewis would like to see the number of marine protected areas in the world increase from 3 per cent to 10 per cent in an attempt to reverse the damage caused by human activity such as overfishing, polluting and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental destruction first-hand. He's swum over coral reefs bleached by the increase in water temperature, and observed underwater deserts beneath the shallow waters of the Red Sea, devoid of life and strewn with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have an unsolvable problem on our hands.
simplified:
Lewis wants to stop the damage to the sea. He wants more 'marine protected areas'. These are parts of the sea that are safe. Now, only 3 per cent of the sea is a protected area. He wants this to be 10 per cent.

People are damaging the sea. They catch too many fish. They also pollute the water and throw rubbish in it. Lewis saw this damage on his trips.

He swam over coral reefs. Coral reefs are like gardens under the sea. Many small animals live there. The water is hotter now, so the coral reefs lost their color. They turned white. He also saw underwater deserts. There was no life there, only plastic.

Lewis thinks nature can get better. But it needs space to do this. We do not have much time. If we do not take care of our seas, we will have a problem. It will be impossible to fix.

During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental destruction first-hand. He's swum over coral reefs bleached by the increase in water temperature, and observed underwater deserts beneath the shallow waters of the Red Sea, devoid of life and strewn with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have an unsolvable problem on our hands.
simplified: Lewis would like to increase the number of protected areas in the sea from 3 to 10 per cent, because he wants to fix the damage that is caused by human activities like overfishing, pollution and leaving rubbish. During his journeys, Lewis has seen this damage to nature with his own eyes. He has swum over coral reefs, which are underwater structures made by small animals, that have turned white because the water is warmer. He has also seen underwater deserts in the Red Sea which have no life and are covered in plastic. Pugh believes that nature can get better if we give it the space to do so, but he thinks we are running out of time. If we don't start taking care of our seas, we may soon have a problem that is impossible to solve.

original: Best-selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell a good story or two, having twice won the Olive Crime Writer Award. Born on the housing estate with the highest crime rate in Glasgow, she learned to keep quiet, stay out of trouble and how to open car doors with a knife. Luckily, she only used her knowledge to write her novels and she's not so quiet these days, appearing on popular daytime shows like Police Today and at writing conferences throughout the UK.
simplified:
Terrie Sharp is a writer. She sells many books. She knows how to tell good stories. She won an important award for crime writers two times.

She was born in Glasgow. She lived in a place with a lot of crime. When she was a child, she learned to be quiet. She learned to not get into trouble. She also learned how to open car doors with a knife.

But she was lucky. She only uses this information for her books. Now, she is not quiet. She is on popular TV shows like 'Police Today'. She also goes to big meetings for writers in the UK.

Luckily, she only used this knowledge to write her books, and she is not so quiet these days because she appears on popular daytime shows like Police Today and at writing conferences all over the UK.

original: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism and distrust, then we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions like democracy and world co-operation.
simplified:
Are things getting worse every day? Is it impossible for things to get better? A writer named Steven Pinker says there is good news. He says we live longer lives now. We are also healthier, more free, and happier.

But Pinker says there is a big problem. The Enlightenment was a time in history. People started to think about reason and science. Today, some people attack these ideas. Some leaders tell people not to trust others. This is very dangerous. It can hurt important things, like democracy. And it can stop countries from working together.

original: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism and distrust, then we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions like democracy and world co-operation.
simplified: Are things getting worse every day, and is progress an impossible goal? In his book *Enlightenment Now*, Steven Pinker looks at the history of human progress and finds good news. He says that we are living longer, healthier, freer, and happier lives. The **Enlightenment** was a period in history when ideas about reason and science became very important. However, Pinker argues that the real problem is that these values are now under attack. He says that some leaders and commentators use people's negative feelings, like distrust. They also use the belief that you cannot change things. When this happens, we are in danger of causing serious damage to important systems like democracy and world co-operation.

original: In older horror films, when protagonists were in desperation, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.
simplified:
In old horror films, the main people were often in danger.
They needed help.
But it was very hard to call the police.
Or it was not possible.

Now, things are different.
Many people have mobile phones.
So this situation is not very real today.
How can horror films be scary now?
What is the answer?
The phone has no signal!

Imagine you are the hero in a horror film.
Something bad is happening.
You really need to call for help.
At that important moment, your phone will not work.
You will have no signal.
Or your phone's battery will stop working.
This happens when you are calling for help.
Sometimes, both things happen.

Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.
simplified: In older horror films, when the main characters were in a very difficult situation, it was hard or impossible for them to call for help or the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less easy to believe now, so writers have found a solution to keep the story exciting: no phone signal. If you are a hero in a horror film, it is almost certain that at an important moment, just when you really need to call for help, you will not have any signal at all. Another possibility is that your phone battery will die just as you are making the call, or sometimes both things happen at the same time.

original: In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's successor – the Cavendish. With its easily transported, thick-skinned and sweet-tasting fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower and exporter in South America at the time, mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible: it cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and cultivated them in densely packed fields.
simplified:
In the 1950s, commercial banana growers in Central America had a big problem. Their most important product for making money was the Gros Michel banana. People also called it Big Mike. This banana was dying.

Now, the same thing is happening again. It is happening to the Cavendish banana. The Cavendish banana is the one that replaced Big Mike.

The Gros Michel banana was very popular. It was easy to move, had thick skin, and was sweet. It was the main banana on almost all the big farms in Central America.

A company called United Fruit grew these bananas. It was the main grower in South America at that time. It found an efficient way to mass-produce them. This means they grew huge numbers of bananas quickly and cheaply. They did not grow new plants from seeds. Instead, they cloned them by taking parts from old plants. They grew these new plants very close together in the fields.

This banana was also known as Big Mike, and now the same thing is happening again to the Cavendish, which is the banana that replaced it. The Gros Michel was the main banana plant on the large farms of Central America because its fruit had a thick skin, which made it easy to transport, and it also tasted sweet. United Fruit, which was the main company that grew and sold bananas in South America at the time, produced them in a very efficient way. Instead of using seeds, the company made exact copies from other plants and grew them very close together in large fields.

original: Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the known spider species produce venom which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. Australia's notorious Sydney funnel-web spider has not produced any fatalities since anti-venom was developed in 1981. However, take care not to rub hairy spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.
simplified:
Venom is a poison from an animal. Most kinds of spiders have venom. They use it to stop or kill their food. They do not use it to hurt people.

Only 25 kinds of spiders can really hurt people with their venom. When a spider hurts you, it can hurt a lot. But people do not often die when a spider hurts them. For example, there is a famous spider in Australia. Its name is the Sydney funnel-web spider. No one has died when this spider hurts them now. This is because doctors made a medicine that stops the poison in 1981.

But you must be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. Do not make them angry. When these spiders are scared, they protect themselves. They send out many special hairs. These hairs get into your skin or eyes. They make them red and sore.

When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.

In fact, only 25 known types of spider make venom that can actually harm humans, and although their bites can be painful, they rarely kill people. For example, Australia's famous Sydney funnel-web spider has not caused any deaths since a special medicine called anti-venom was created in 1981. However, you should be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. When they feel they are in danger, they defend themselves by shooting out a cloud of special hairs, and these annoying hairs can get stuck in the skin or eyes of an attacker.

original: This horror film cliché was especially popular with horror films of the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers all enjoying themselves, and it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At the beginning the girl is usually innocent, shy and not particularly strong. By the end, she has become the toughest and most resourceful person in the world. The last girl almost always wins in the end.
simplified:
There is a story you see many times in horror films.
This story was very popular in older films.
It starts with a group of young people.
They are all happy and having fun.
But at the end, everyone is dead.
Only one girl is alive.
At the start of the film, this girl is good and shy.
She is not very strong.
But at the end, she changes.
She becomes the strongest and cleverest person.
This last girl usually wins.

original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified:
To understand where our ability for difficult language came from, we need to look at our brains.
Our brains are different from animal brains.
The size of the brain is not the only important thing.
It is also important to know what our brains can do.
We also need to know why they changed over a long time.
We do not have much information about this.
Old things from people long ago do not tell us how they talked.
But we can look at old bones from early people.
These show how their mouths, throats, and tongues changed.
About 100,000 years ago, humans got the ability to make difficult sounds.
Scientists can only guess about the time before this.
They are not sure if early people talked with simple sounds.

original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified:
If we want to know where our ability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This is about more than just the size of the brain, because it is also important what our brains can do and why they developed in that way. However, there is very little physical evidence for this, and the objects that people from the past left behind don't tell us what kind of speech they were able to make.

One thing we can see from the bodies of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had developed the ability to create complex sounds. Before that time, scientists can only guess whether early humans used more basic sounds to communicate with each other.

original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models youngsters see doing science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified:
Society tells us that girls should like art. It tells us boys should like maths and physics. This idea comes from people, not from nature.
Also, girls do not see good examples of women in science jobs. This is a problem. In cartoons and stories, the scientist is often a man. He is a crazy scientist, a great inventor, or an astronaut.
People also have wrong ideas about scientists. The media shows these false ideas. These ideas are called stereotypes. People think scientists are not good with other people. They think scientists work alone.
Because of this, girls may not want to be scientists. They may think science is not an interesting job for them.
If girls see more women scientists, it helps them. They will feel more sure of themselves. They will feel that they are part of the world of science.

Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified: Society, not nature, tells us that girls should prefer arts subjects, while boys should study maths and physics. In addition, there is a lack of positive female role models who young people can see working in science-related jobs. For example, cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist or brave astronaut as a man. There is also a negative idea that scientists are not very social, or that their work is lonely and separate from the rest of the world. These are false **stereotypes**, which are simple but often untrue ideas about a group of people, that are shown by the media. However, they may mean that girls do not feel a connection with scientists and see science as a career that is not interesting for them. If girls saw more positive female role models in science, it would give them more confidence and help them feel that they belong in those subjects.

original: The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in faculty buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. The survey shows that the newspaper is highly valued by university students and staff for entertainment, cultural enrichment and work experience. The cost of printing newspapers is significant. Furthermore, some students do not have easy access to the paper, since the only way to obtain a copy is to physically go to university. An additional environmental issue is that a large number of copies end up as litter on campus.
simplified:
"The Scallion" is a newspaper. It comes out every week. It is free. You can find it in faculty buildings. About 10,000 students read it.

Only students write and make the newspaper. A study shows that students and staff really like the newspaper. They read it for fun. They also learn a lot about culture from it. It gives students good work experience too.

But there are some problems. It costs a lot of money to make the newspaper. Also, some students cannot get the paper easily. You have to go to the university to get one. It is also a problem for the environment. Many copies become litter on campus.

The cost of printing the newspaper is high. Also, some students cannot get the paper easily, because the only way to get a copy is to go to the university in person. Another problem for the environment is that many copies become rubbish on the campus.

original: At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an annual employee turnover of about 12 per cent. Although this might not seem high at first glance, the industry standard is seven per cent. The principal objective of this report is to investigate the causes of employee engagement within the firm and, based on those, offer recommendations to improve the employees' experience of the workplace and increase employee retention.
simplified:
Turnover is when workers leave a company. Retention is when workers stay at a company for a long time.

At our company, Girox Foods, we have a problem. Our turnover is about 12% every year. Many workers leave our company.

This number is high. For other similar companies, the number is only 7%.

This report has one main goal. We will study the reasons why workers stay or leave. Then, we will explain how to make the company a better place to work. We want our workers to stay with us. We want to increase our retention.

The principal objective of this report is to investigate the causes of employee engagement within the firm and, based on those, offer recommendations to improve the employees' experience of the workplace and increase employee retention.
simplified: At Girox Foods, we have an employee **turnover**, which is the rate at which people leave the company, of about 12 per cent each year. Although this might not seem high at first, the average for our industry is only seven per cent. The main goal of this report is to find out the reasons why our employees are not happy at work and, based on those reasons, offer suggestions to make the company a better place to work. This should also help to increase employee **retention**, which means making sure more employees decide to stay with us.

original: So much of what the speaker said rang true. I honestly believe there's a danger that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I don't think this is such an issue for my generation who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know that it's OK to be alone. But the under 20s are another kettle of fish. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of solitude and run the risk of not learning how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they're learning conversation through messages that can be edited and changed at the expense of learning the art of real conversation in real time with the person in front of you.
simplified:
What the speaker said is very true. I really think there is a danger with technology. We connect more with people online. But this can make us feel more alone.

This is not a big problem for people my age. We lived for a long time without technology. We know how to be alone. We also know it is okay to be alone.

But young people are very different. They are always talking to other people. So they never experience solitude. Solitude is when you are alone. They may not learn to enjoy time with only themselves.

Also, they learn to talk with messages. They can change these messages. This stops them from learning how to have a real conversation. A real conversation is with another person. That person is with you.

I don't think this is a big problem for my generation, because we have lived without technology for a long time and we know that it's okay to be alone. However, the situation is completely different for people under 20. They are so busy communicating that they never experience **solitude, which is the feeling of being alone**, and there is a risk they won't learn how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they are learning conversation through messages that can be edited, which means they are not learning the skill of having a real conversation with the person in front of them.

original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given for its own sake and resist the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
simplified: Feedback is when you tell someone if their work is good or bad. Don't always give good feedback and then bad feedback. If you do this, the good words are not special anymore. They lose their power. So, sometimes you should only give good feedback. Do not give any bad feedback after it.

original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given for its own sake and resist the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
simplified: You should not always give positive **feedback**, which is information about how well someone is doing something, at the same time as negative feedback. If you always give positive and negative comments together, the positive feedback can become less important and people may start to ignore it. For this reason, you should make sure there are times when you only give positive feedback, and you should avoid offering criticism at the same time.
